results.title: A Boys' winter games lesson
results.creator_credit: Gaumont-British Instructional and Andrew Miller Jones
results.brief_description: This film shows a typical organised field games lesson for a class of boys aged 11 from an elementary school in a congested area of a big city. The lesson includes Association football and Rugby Touch, together with group practices leading up to these games. Based on British Board of Education Syllabus of Physical Training for Schools, 1933.

results.title: A Boy, a dog and a frog
results.creator_credit: Evergreen Films, John Sturner and Gary Templeton
results.brief_description: This film follows the adventures of a small boy and his dog as they spend a day trying to capture a playful frog at a nearby pond. The film is a delightful, non-verbal production that will provide amusement and enjoyment for audiences of all ages.

results.title: A Boy of the Netherlands
results.brief_description: The experiences of a Dutch farm boy when he travels by cargo barge to Amsterdam along the canals of Holland. He learns about life on board ship; and something of the industries of his country. The highlight of his visit to Amsterdam is a tour of city shops. Suitable for middle and upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: A Boy of the Navajos
results.brief_description: This is the story of Tony Hotinez a present-day Navajo boy. It recounts his adventures as he herds sheep in the Arizona desert, spends evenings with his family in their hogan, and takes an exciting trip to the trading post, where Tony sells the drawings of the Navajos and of their customs which he has made. Suitable for middle and upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: A Boy of the circus
results.brief_description: Dino, the only one of his family not employed at the circus, visits an opening performance to try to interest them in giving him a job. We see how circus people work together to produce a spectacle in which Dino finally plays a part.

results.title: A Boy of India: Rama and his elephant
results.brief_description: This is the story of Rama, an eight-year-old boy who lives with his family on a tea plantation in Assam, India. The story tells of a very special day in Rama’s life. Accompanying his father, a mahout, to learn how he handles his work elephant, Rama for the first time works with the elephant Gunda as she pulls a stalled tea truck from the stream. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: A Boy creates
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Bert Van Bork
results.brief_description: Traces a young boy’s venture into creating a sculpture of “found art”. He collects cast-off wood, metal and plastic objects from an amusement park and proceeds to a mud flat to create his figure. Other sculptures of similar materials are also assembled here in an open air “gallery”. As he works the film depicts the boy’s fanciful flights and shows the possibilities for artistic expression are infinite when aided by resourcefulness and imagination No commentary, music only.

results.title: A Boy's life
results.brief_description: Although embracing vastly different styles and aesthetices, the three films comprising “A boy’s life” present an intriguingly lucid biography of developing sexuality - from childhood via puberty to college days. Using humour to explore painful issues of emerging identity, both ‘Dottie Gets Spanked’ (director, Todd Haynes) and ‘Trevor’ (director, Peggy Rajski) are remarkable in that they address one of the ultimate taboos by acknowledging that children can and do have an awareness of their own sexuality. The third short film, ‘A Friend of Dorothy’ this is the tale of a sexually confused young man in his first term at college. Each film rings with authenticity: they represent stories, experiences and emotions that many gay men will instantly recognise.

results.title: A Bout de Souffle = Breathless (Reserve Print)
results.creator_credit: Georges de Beauregard and Jean-Luc Godard
results.brief_description:
Michel, on the run after shooting a policeman, is betrayed by his girlfriend, Patricia, an expatriate American. The plot is drawn from the ‘B’ crime thriller (the film is dedicated to Monogram Pictures, Hollywood’s all-B movie studio) and Godard pays homage to Hollywood’s action genres but his free approach to narrative and stylistics made this the most original and influential of the early New Wave films. The theme of the limits of personal freedom on the boundary between anarchism and nihilism emerges almost casually. The sense of dislocation is most obvious in Godard’s use of the jump cut, a device which he rarely, if ever, used again although he retained the effect. A more accurate translation of the title is ‘out of breath’ rather than the more romantic ‘breathless’.

Credits: Producer, Georges de Beauregard ; director, writer, Jean-Luc Godard ; photography, Raoul Coutard ; music, Martial Solal.
Cast: Jean-Paul Belmondo, Jean Seberg, Jean-Pierre Melville, Roger Hanin, Daniel Boulanger, Richard Balducci.
